Multi-Modal Recommendation Unlearning

Yash Sinha
School of Computing
National University of Singapore
yashsinha@comp.nus.edu.sg
Murari Mandal
RespAI Lab
KIIT Bhubaneswar, India
murari.mandalfcs@kiit.ac.in
Mohan Kankanhalli
School of Computing
National University of Singapore
mohan@comp.nus.edu.sg
Abstract

Unlearning methods for recommender systems (RS) have emerged to address privacy issues and concerns about legal compliance. However, evolving user preferences and content licensing issues still remain unaddressed. This is particularly true in case of multi-modal recommender systems (MMRS), which aim to accommodate the growing influence of multi-modal information on user preferences. Previous unlearning methods for RS are inapplicable to MMRS due to incompatibility of multi-modal user-item behavior data graph with the matrix based representation of RS. Partitioning based methods degrade recommendation performance and incur significant overhead costs during aggregation. This paper introduces MMRecUN, a new framework for multi-modal recommendation unlearning, which, to the best of our knowledge, is the first attempt in this direction. Given the trained recommendation model and marked forget data, we devise Reverse Bayesian Personalized Ranking (BPR) objective to force the model to forget it. MMRecUN employs both reverse and forward BPR loss mechanisms to selectively attenuate the impact of interactions within the forget set while concurrently reinforcing the significance of interactions within the retain set. Our experiments demonstrate that MMRecUN outperforms baseline methods across various unlearning requests when evaluated on benchmark multi-modal recommender datasets. MMRecUN achieves recall performance improvements of up to 49.85%percent49.85\mathbf{49.85\%}bold_49.85 % compared to the baseline methods. It is up to 1.3×\mathbf{1.3}\timesbold_1.3 × faster than the Gold model, which is trained on retain data from scratch. MMRecUN offers advantages such as superior performance in removing target elements, preservation of performance for retained elements, and zero overhead costs in comparison to previous methods. Code will be released after review.

1 Introduction

Recommender systems [38] [18](RS), utilizing techniques such as collaborative filtering, content-based filtering, and neural networks, have transformed online experiences by offering personalized recommendations for diverse content types, including movies, music, products, news articles, etc. thus improving user engagement and satisfaction. As user preferences are getting influenced by multi-modal information [10], multimedia recommendation is gaining attention in recent times [48] [62]. Recent works [54] [31] [46] [45] [51] model user preferences based on both behavior information and item multi-modal information. With the rising demands for data privacy, regulations like GDPR [42], CCPA [15], and LGPD [19] emphasize user rights towards data protection and “be forgotten”. While user privacy [59] [55] has been addressed through unlearning user-related data in RS [4] [25]; the unlearning of item-related data in multi-modal recommender systems (MMRS) remains unexplored.

Motivation. We discuss some recent events and other probable scenarios where multi-modal recommender unlearning would be a great support:

Complex content licensing agreements: The recent decision by Universal Music Group (UMG) [21] to pull its library off from TikTok, silencing millions of user-created videos, requires TikTok’s RS to adapt to the absence of UMG content. The 2020 lawsuit [11] against Spotify by Wixen Music Publishing regarding songwriters’ compensation may potentially influence the effectiveness of the underlying recommendation algorithm. The 2016 dispute [24] between YouTube and Warner Music Group led to temporary content removal. So, there is a potential for conflict between existing models and evolving contractual obligations, underscoring the need for adaptable RS.

Legal compliance: The Algorithmic Accountability Act [17] underscores the responsibility of companies to evaluate their machine learning systems for bias and discrimination. Current RS, however, often reinforce existing user preferences, perpetuating stereotypes and limiting diversity through filter bubbles and echo chambers  [5] [29]. This necessitates systems to personalize effectively and promote fairness and exposure to diverse viewpoints.

Evolving user interests in different modalities: Consider a user who typically posts content related to fitness and healthy living. However, over time, she develops a new interest in travel photography and shares photos and stories from her recent trips to exotic locations. While the images and hashtags reflect passion for travel, the recommender system continues to prioritize fitness-related content in its recommendations. By analyzing both text and image modalities, the system can provide more relevant and personalized recommendations, enhancing the user’s browsing experience.

Selective unlearning based on modalities: In the case of UMG removing its library from TikTok, the recommender system needs to adapt to the absence of UMG audio content while still considering other modalities like videos. In MMRS, both the graph structure and feature embeddings are tightly integrated. Unlearning interactions in one modality may have cascading effects on the representations and relationships within the entire graph.

Aiding selective transfer: With the growing concern for data privacy, cross-domain recommendation models face challenges in accessing domain-shareable user-item information across different platforms. Traditional assumptions of such models become impractical due to strict data privacy protection policies [32]. Sharing information across domains can be beneficial, but it can also lead to negative transfer. Imagine a movie recommendation system where the source domain is horror movies and the target domain is comedies. Sharing horror movie ratings might not be helpful for recommending comedies. Unlearning algorithms can be used to identify and remove irrelevant or misleading information from the source domain data before transferring it to the target domain.

Multi-modal recommendation unlearning that works for both user-related data and item-related data can be a promising response to these multifaceted challenges. By enabling systems to dynamically update their models and remove previously learned associations with unavailable or irrelevant content, unlearning holds the potential to enhance user privacy, ensure legal compliance, adapt to changing content licensing and evolve with user choices. It can also mitigate recommendation bias and data poisoning. Moreover, unlearning can reduce the GPU-hours carbon footprint that results from repeated retraining from scratch.

Background and Related Work. RS can be categorized into various types based on their underlying techniques. These include collaborative filtering (CF), matrix factorization (MF), content-based filtering (CBF), sequential recommender systems (SRS), graph convolutional network-based (GCN) and hybrids of these systems. While pioneering works have explored various unlearning approaches [34], previous unlearning methods for RS using MF  [30] [50] [33] [60], CF  [28] [37], or SRS [52] typically operate on behavior matrices. This approach makes them incompatible with multi-modal GCN-based RS which rely on bipartite graph representations. Even unlearning methods for uni-modal GCN-based RS, whether exact or approximate, face challenges in transitioning to multi-modal GCN-based systems due to the intricate integration of diverse modalities [7]. Unlearning interactions within one modality can cascade through the entire graph, impacting its representations and relationships. Approximate unlearning [53] [61] [26] entail computationally expensive operations, such as calculating the inverse of Hessian matrix for influence functions and the Fisher Information Matrix. Consequently, they are impractical for MMRS with large number of feature dimensions. Exact unlearning [4] [25] methods adapt SISA [1] to partitioning the dataset into shards. However, this approach disrupts the graph structure and leads to performance drops within each shard due to insufficient training data and poor data heterogeneity [22]. Moreover, efforts to preserve data structure and aggregate performance across shards introduce significant overhead costs, impacting both training and inference procedures, with the burden increasing proportionally to the number of shards [35]. Further, when users that need to be forgotten come from multiple shards, it effectively falls back to retraining from scratch. Most importantly, their primary focus remains on user privacy through unlearning user-related data, overlooking the crucial need for unlearning item-related data to address evolving content licensing, legal compliance, or user preferences. These constraints underscore the need for tailored methodologies specifically designed for unlearning in MMRS. The supplementary material (Appendix H) provides further insights into the challenges and other previous works  [7] [56] [27] [3] [13] [49] [44].

Our contributions. The main contributions are summarized as follows:

  1. 1.

    We propose MMRecUN, a comprehensive framework for multi-modal recommendation unlearning. We define the problem of user and item unlearning in MMRS. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first attempt towards unlearning in MMRS.

  2. 2.

    Our work consider a variety of unlearning requests, such as single interaction removal, adjusting user preferences or eliminating bias based on multiple interaction removal, account deletion by removing all interactions of a user, and item removal by eliminating all interactions related to an item. Particularly, we clearly define three metrics for effectively measuring unlearning in MMRS. The paper also introduces and employs, item-centric metrics for evaluating item-unlearning along with user-centric metrics. The previous unlearning methods only used user-centric metrics.

  3. 3.

    The experiments demonstrate that MMRecUN outperforms the baselines across various unlearning requests. It achieves recall performance improvements of up to 49.85%percent49.85\mathbf{49.85\%}bold_49.85 % compared to the baseline methods. It is up to 1.3×\mathbf{1.3}\timesbold_1.3 × faster than the Gold model, which is trained on retain data from scratch.Additionally, MMRecUN offers advantages such as enhanced efficiency, superior performance in removing target elements, preservation of performance for retained elements, and minimal overhead costs.

Problem Formulation. Given a sparse behavior graph 𝒢𝒢\mathcal{G}caligraphic_G and a RS model M⁢(⋅,φ)𝑀⋅𝜑M(\cdot,\varphi)italic_M ( ⋅ , italic_φ ), devise an unlearning algorithm U𝑈Uitalic_U, that unlearns the forget set 𝒟fsubscript𝒟𝑓\mathcal{D}_{f}caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT to obtain an unlearned model M⁢(⋅,φu)𝑀⋅subscript𝜑𝑢M(\cdot,\varphi_{u})italic_M ( ⋅ , italic_φ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_u end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) with updated parameters such that φusubscript𝜑𝑢\varphi_{u}italic_φ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_u end_POSTSUBSCRIPT closely approximates the performance of the gold model:

Properties of MMRS Unlearning. A close approximation requires that the unlearned model possess the following properties:

Unlearning Specificity. The unlearning algorithm U𝑈Uitalic_U should effectively remove the influence of entities in 𝒟fsubscript𝒟𝑓\mathcal{D}_{f}caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT: f⁢(Df,ϵf)𝑓subscript𝐷𝑓subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑓f(D_{f},\epsilon_{f})italic_f ( italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_ϵ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ). The parameters φusubscript𝜑𝑢\varphi_{u}italic_φ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_u end_POSTSUBSCRIPT should lead to a probability distribution that closely aligns with the gold model’s probability distribution. If ϵfsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑓\epsilon_{f}italic_ϵ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is high, the unlearning process is not very successful in reducing the influence of the forget set. Conversely, if ϵfsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑓\epsilon_{f}italic_ϵ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is low, it suggests a potential Streisand effect where the forget set is actually made more noticeable due to extensive unlearning. So, ϵfsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑓\epsilon_{f}italic_ϵ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT should tend to zero.

Retention Fidelity. Equally important is preserving performance of the model. So the probability distribution on test set should align: f⁢(Dt,ϵt)𝑓subscript𝐷𝑡subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑡f(D_{t},\epsilon_{t})italic_f ( italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_ϵ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ). A high value of ϵtsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑡\epsilon_{t}italic_ϵ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT indicates that the model’s utility is compromised, as it becomes excessively tailored to the specific traits of the retain set. On the other hand, if ϵtsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑡\epsilon_{t}italic_ϵ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is low, it indicates that the unlearning process has inadvertently led to the loss of characteristics of the retain set. So, ϵtsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑡\epsilon_{t}italic_ϵ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT should tend to zero.

Unlearning Generalizability. The unlearning algorithm U𝑈Uitalic_U should ensure that the unlearning process does not inadvertently introduce biases or distortions that affect the model’s generalization ability. This is evaluated by comparing scores on unseen data, which verifies that the unlearning process maintains the model’s performance on data that was not used for either training or unlearning: f⁢(Dv,ϵv)𝑓subscript𝐷𝑣subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑣f(D_{v},\epsilon_{v})italic_f ( italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_ϵ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ). A high value of ϵvsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑣\epsilon_{v}italic_ϵ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT suggests that the unlearning process might have overly tailored the model to the specific traits of the retain set during the forget process, leading to a loss of generalization ability. Conversely, if ϵvsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑣\epsilon_{v}italic_ϵ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is low, it indicates that the unlearning process has successfully retained the essential characteristics of the retain set while removing the influence of the forget set.

Unlearning Efficiency. The unlearning process should be faster than retraining the model from scratch. It should be efficient in terms of time and computational resources.

3 Proposed MMRecUN Method

There are two stages of training a recommender model M⁢(⋅,φ)𝑀⋅𝜑M(\cdot,\varphi)italic_M ( ⋅ , italic_φ ) and inference. The optimization process (more details presented in Appendix B) involves minimizing the Bayesian Personalized Ranking (BPR) loss ℒBPRsubscriptℒBPR\mathcal{L}_{\text{BPR}}caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT BPR end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [36]:

We tabulate all the possible unlearning requests in Table 1. After receiving an unlearning request, the recommendation system must execute two processes. First, remove data by nullifying interaction data in the interaction matrix, yu,i=0subscript𝑦𝑢𝑖0y_{u,i}=0italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_u , italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 0, ∀yu,i∈𝒴u+for-allsubscript𝑦𝑢𝑖superscriptsubscript𝒴𝑢\forall y_{u,i}\in\mathcal{Y}_{u}^{+}∀ italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_u , italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ caligraphic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_u end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Second, retrain the recommendation model M⁢(⋅,φ)𝑀⋅𝜑M(\cdot,\varphi)italic_M ( ⋅ , italic_φ ) using the updated interaction matrix 𝒴𝒴\mathcal{Y}caligraphic_Y. However, this is not efficient. Hence, we propose to unlearn the trained model M⁢(⋅,φ)𝑀⋅𝜑M(\cdot,\varphi)italic_M ( ⋅ , italic_φ ) using MMRecUN. The overall process of training, inference, and unlearning is depicted in Figure 1.

Reverse Bayesian Personalized Ranking Objective. To achieve the objectives of unlearning in recommender systems, MMRecUN employs a reverse objective inspired by the concept of amnesiac unlearning [16]. This approach suggests selectively undoing the learning steps associated with a forget set 𝒟fsubscript𝒟𝑓\mathcal{D}_{f}caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, essentially removing the parameter updates related to forgotten data points and thus minimizing the predicted probability to a sufficiently small value. This works well for traditional machine learning tasks like image classification. Extending it to our context of recommender systems, the reverse objective of user u𝑢uitalic_u for her marked interactions is: minimize the predicted score of marked interactions relative to items with which she did not interact.

min⁡ℒRPR=∑u∈𝒰∑i∈𝒴u+⁢j∈𝒴u−ln⁡σ⁢(y^u,i−y^u,j)subscriptℒRPRsubscript𝑢𝒰subscript𝑖superscriptsubscript𝒴𝑢𝑗superscriptsubscript𝒴𝑢𝜎subscript^𝑦𝑢𝑖subscript^𝑦𝑢𝑗\min\mathcal{L}_{\text{RPR}}=\sum_{u\in\mathcal{U}}\sum_{\begin{subarray}{c}i% \in\mathcal{Y}_{u}^{+}j\in\mathcal{Y}_{u}^{-}\end{subarray}}\ln\sigma(\hat{y}_% {u,i}-\hat{y}_{u,j})roman_min caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT RPR end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_u ∈ caligraphic_U end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_ARG start_ROW start_CELL italic_i ∈ caligraphic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_u end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_j ∈ caligraphic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_u end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_CELL end_ROW end_ARG end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ln italic_σ ( over^ start_ARG italic_y end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_u , italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - over^ start_ARG italic_y end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_u , italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) (5)

However, in the process of updating the embeddings of the recommendation model according to this reverse objective, there is a risk of catastrophic forgetting of previously learned data in the retain set 𝒟rsubscript𝒟𝑟\mathcal{D}_{r}caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_r end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, potentially leading to inaccurate recommendations. Therefore, it becomes crucial to carefully balance the trade-off between retention fidelity and unlearning specificity. To this end, MMRecUN employs the original training objective to adapt such forgetting of the retain set 𝒟rsubscript𝒟𝑟\mathcal{D}_{r}caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_r end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

ℒadaptsubscriptℒadapt\displaystyle\mathcal{L}_{\text{adapt}}caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT adapt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT =ℒBPR+λC⁢ℒC+λφ⁢‖φ‖2absentsubscriptℒBPRsubscript𝜆𝐶subscriptℒ𝐶subscript𝜆𝜑superscriptnorm𝜑2\displaystyle=\mathcal{L}_{\text{BPR}}+\lambda_{C}\mathcal{L}_{C}+\lambda_{% \varphi}\|\varphi\|^{2}= caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT BPR end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_λ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_λ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_φ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∥ italic_φ ∥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT (6)

However, this introduces more epochs of contrastive auxiliary loss ℒCsubscriptℒ𝐶\mathcal{L}_{C}caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, which encourages the model to learn representations that are invariant to irrelevant variations in the data and, L2subscript𝐿2L_{2}italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT regularization term which controls the complexity of the model by penalizing large parameter values. These epochs can cause over-fitting on the retain set, 𝒟rsubscript𝒟𝑟\mathcal{D}_{r}caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_r end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Hence we introduce negated contrastive auxiliary loss and regularization term to discourage the model from maintaining such invariance and reduce the influence of previously learned parameters when reversing the learning process.

ℒreformsubscriptℒreform\displaystyle\mathcal{L}_{\text{reform}}caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT reform end_POSTSUBSCRIPT =ℒRPR−(λC⁢ℒC+λφ⁢‖φ‖2)absentsubscriptℒRPRsubscript𝜆𝐶subscriptℒ𝐶subscript𝜆𝜑superscriptnorm𝜑2\displaystyle=\mathcal{L}_{\text{RPR}}-(\lambda_{C}\mathcal{L}_{C}+\lambda_{% \varphi}\|\varphi\|^{2})= caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT RPR end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - ( italic_λ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_λ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_φ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∥ italic_φ ∥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) (7)

Finally, the loss function becomes

ℒ=α⋅ℒadapt+(1−α)⋅ℒreformℒ⋅𝛼subscriptℒadapt⋅1𝛼subscriptℒreform\displaystyle\mathcal{L}=\alpha\cdot\mathcal{L}_{\mathrm{adapt}}+(1-\alpha)% \cdot\mathcal{L}_{\mathrm{reform}}caligraphic_L = italic_α ⋅ caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_adapt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + ( 1 - italic_α ) ⋅ caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_reform end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (8)

where α𝛼\alphaitalic_α is a hyper-parameter that determines the relative importance of adapt and reform.

Proposition 1

(Bayesian Interpretation of MMRecUN). The MMRecUN objective function in Eq. 5 can be interpreted through the Bayes theorem. Let the learning process be regarded as maximizing the posterior distribution estimated by φφ\varphiitalic_φ, i.e., max⁡P⁢(φ|𝒟)Pconditionalφ𝒟\max P(\varphi|\mathcal{D})roman_max italic_P ( italic_φ | caligraphic_D ), with a certain prior distribution of g⁢(φ)gφg(\varphi)italic_g ( italic_φ ). The detailed proof is given in Appendix C.

The Kullback-Leibler (KL) divergence [23, 14, 41] is difficult to implement in RS because the typical user-item interaction data are not inherently probabilistic but based on scores or ratings. Further, KL Divergence can be undefined when the target distribution has zero probability for an event that the input distribution considers likely, which can be problematic in sparse and high-dimensional recommendation datasets. Therefore, we propose BPR (Bayesian Personalized Ranking) divergence as an alternative which directly measures the difference between the predicted scores of user-item interactions from different model states using mean squared error, which aligns well with the numerical nature of recommendation scores.

BPR_divergence⁢(φ,φ′)BPR_divergence𝜑superscript𝜑′\displaystyle\text{BPR\_divergence}(\varphi,\varphi^{\prime})BPR_divergence ( italic_φ , italic_φ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) =1|𝒴u+|⁢∑i∈𝒴u+(y^u,i−y^u,i′)2+1|𝒴u−|⁢∑j∈𝒴u−(y^u,j−y^u,j′)2absent1superscriptsubscript𝒴𝑢subscript𝑖superscriptsubscript𝒴𝑢superscriptsubscript^𝑦𝑢𝑖superscriptsubscript^𝑦𝑢𝑖′21superscriptsubscript𝒴𝑢subscript𝑗superscriptsubscript𝒴𝑢superscriptsubscript^𝑦𝑢𝑗superscriptsubscript^𝑦𝑢𝑗′2\displaystyle=\frac{1}{|\mathcal{Y}_{u}^{+}|}\sum_{i\in\mathcal{Y}_{u}^{+}}(% \hat{y}_{u,i}-\hat{y}_{u,i}^{{}^{\prime}})^{2}+\frac{1}{|\mathcal{Y}_{u}^{-}|}% \sum_{j\in\mathcal{Y}_{u}^{-}}(\hat{y}_{u,j}-\hat{y}_{u,j}^{{}^{\prime}})^{2}= divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG | caligraphic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_u end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | end_ARG ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i ∈ caligraphic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_u end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( over^ start_ARG italic_y end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_u , italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - over^ start_ARG italic_y end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_u , italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG | caligraphic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_u end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | end_ARG ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j ∈ caligraphic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_u end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( over^ start_ARG italic_y end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_u , italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - over^ start_ARG italic_y end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_u , italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT (10)

As depicted in Figure 2(a), the BPR divergence decreases between the gold and unlearned models on the forget set 𝒟fsubscript𝒟𝑓\mathcal{D}_{f}caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT as epochs increase. For detailed derivation see Appendix D.

4 Experiments and Results

4.1 Experiment Settings

Datasets and baselines. We use three distinct categories within the Amazon dataset [20] that are used to benchmark MMRS (see Appendix E). The model trained on the retain set (named as the Gold model) from scratch is used as baseline. We prepare another baseline by re-purposing the image classification unlearning AmUn [16] for multi-model recommender unlearning.

Previous RS unlearning methods using matrix factorization, collaborative filtering, or sequential recommendation systems operate on behavior matrices, making them incompatible with graph-based architectures. The code for approximate methods Rrl, Ifru, and Scif is unavailable. Exact methods, RecEraser and UltraRE, require partitioning, which is challenging due to the need for specialized handling of each modality and ensuring coherence during aggregation, adding complexity outside the scope of this work.

Evaluation metrics To evaluate a given recommendation model M⁢(⋅,φ)𝑀⋅𝜑M(\cdot,\varphi)italic_M ( ⋅ , italic_φ ), we need model predictions: the ranked list of user-item pairs; the ground truth: user-item interactions 𝒴𝒴\mathcal{Y}caligraphic_Y; and, K𝐾Kitalic_K: the number of the top recommendations to consider. To capture a variety of aspects of performance, we use predictive metrics, that reflect the “correctness", how well M⁢(⋅,φ)𝑀⋅𝜑M(\cdot,\varphi)italic_M ( ⋅ , italic_φ ) finds relevant items such as Recall at K and Precision at K; and ranking metrics, that reflect the ranking quality, how well M⁢(⋅,φ)𝑀⋅𝜑M(\cdot,\varphi)italic_M ( ⋅ , italic_φ ) can sort the items from more relevant to less relevant. NDCG considers both the relevance and the position of items in the ranked list. MAP measures the average Precision across different Recall levels for a ranked list.

Settings and Hyper-parameters All the experiments are performed on 4444x NVIDIA RTX2080 (32323232GB). We use the identical settings as in the case of Mgcn for training the original recommender model M⁢(⋅,φ)𝑀⋅𝜑M(\cdot,\varphi)italic_M ( ⋅ , italic_φ ). The data interaction history of each user is split 8:1:1:81:18:1:18 : 1 : 1 for training, validation and testing. The training set is used to create retain set and forget set. We initialize the embedding with Xavier initialization of dimension 64646464, set the regularization coefficient to λφ=10−4subscript𝜆𝜑superscript104\lambda_{\varphi}=10^{-4}italic_λ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_φ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 10 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 4 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, and the batch size to B=2048𝐵2048B=2048italic_B = 2048. For the self-supervised task, we set the temperature to 0.20.20.20.2. For convergence, the early stopping and total epochs are fixed at 20202020 and 1000100010001000, respectively. We use Recall@20 on the validation data as the training-stopping indicator following [58]. We conducted experiments five times using different seed values and report the standard deviation values for item unlearning in Table 3. For the other types of unlearning, the standard deviation values were found to be negligible and are therefore omitted.

4.2 Results

We conduct experiments to assess the unlearning performance of MMRecUN in the four aspects. First, we compare recall, precision, NDCG and MAP metrics on forget set. Values closer to the Gold model signify better Unlearning Specificity. Second, we compare the metrics on test set. Values closer to the Gold model signify better Retention Fidelity. Third, we compare the metrics on validation set. Values closer to the Gold model signify better Unlearning Generalizability. Finally, we compare the time duration required for unlearning to compare efficiency.

User-centric metrics measure the relevance from user’s perspective i.e., whether the relevant items (the user likes or interacts with) are present in the top K𝐾Kitalic_K recommendations. Users typically expect to see a small number of recommendations (e.g., 5555 or 10101010), hence we take K=5,10,20,50𝐾5102050K=5,10,20,50italic_K = 5 , 10 , 20 , 50 to assess how well the system can provide personalized and focused recommendations. Larger values of K𝐾Kitalic_K, such as 20202020 or 50505050, are useful for evaluating the system’s ability to cover a wider range of user preferences or measure performance in suggesting diverse options and catering to different user tastes. These metrics primarily focus on user satisfaction and do not capture the effectiveness of forgetting specific items. Hence, for item-unlearning, we introduce several item-centric metrics as well.

Item-centric metrics measure the relevance of the recommended items themselves i.e., how well the recommended items meet unlearning criteria, regardless of which users receive them. We take K=500,1000,1500𝐾50010001500K=500,1000,1500italic_K = 500 , 1000 , 1500 to ensure that all items in the forget set 𝒟fsubscript𝒟𝑓\mathcal{D}_{f}caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are considered for evaluating performance.

User Unlearning. Table 2 presents the results of unlearning 5%percent55\%5 % users. The Gold model, which has never seen the forget set, falls in performance on this set as expected. However, it retains good performance on the test and validation sets. On the validation set, MMRecUN consistently achieves better recall scores, outperforming AmUn by 29.6%percent29.629.6\%29.6 %, 49.85%percent49.8549.85\%49.85 %, and 34.75%percent34.7534.75\%34.75 % on the three datasets (baby, sports, and clothing, respectively), showcasing best unlearning generalizability. Furthermore, on the test set, MMRecUN maintains closest recall scores, surpassing AmUn by 26.69%percent26.6926.69\%26.69 %, 46.93%percent46.9346.93\%46.93 %, and 36.13%percent36.1336.13\%36.13 %, demonstrating best retention fidelity. On the forget set, MMRecUN achieves better recall scores, outperforming AmUn by 3.8%percent3.83.8\%3.8 % and 43.75%percent43.7543.75\%43.75 % on two datasets and slightly falling back by 2.08%percent2.082.08\%2.08 % on the clothing dataset, indicating high unlearning specificity. Similar trends follow for other metrics.

Item Unlearning Table 3 presents the results of unlearning 5%percent55\%5 % items. On the validation set, the recall scores differ by 2.21%percent2.212.21\%2.21 %, 0.65%percent0.650.65\%0.65 %, and 0.41%percent0.410.41\%0.41 % on the three datasets (baby, sports, and clothing, respectively), showcasing comparable unlearning generalizability. Similarly, on the test set, the recall scores differ by 1.43%percent1.431.43\%1.43 %, 0.13%percent0.130.13\%0.13 %, and 0.10%percent0.100.10\%0.10 %, demonstrating comparable retention fidelity. However, MMRecUN achieves good recall scores, outperforming AmUn by 10.83%percent10.8310.83\%10.83 % and 8.45%percent8.458.45\%8.45 % on two datasets and slightly falling back by 3.43%percent3.433.43\%3.43 % on the sports dataset, indicating high unlearning specificity.

User and Item Unlearning. Table 4 presents the results of unlearning both 5%percent55\%5 % users and 5%percent55\%5 % items. On user-centric metrics, the performance of AmUn and MMRecUN is comparable. The recall scores differ by 2.89%percent2.892.89\%2.89 %, 1.83%percent1.831.83\%1.83 % and 0%percent00\%0 % approximately across three datasets on the validation set, test set and forget set, respectively, showcasing comparable unlearning generalizability, retention fidelity and unlearning specificity. On item-centric metrics, MMRecUN achieves recall score up to 41.32%percent41.3241.32\%41.32 % higher than AmUn on forget set, indicating high unlearning specificity. The recall scores differ by 2.14%percent2.142.14\%2.14 % and 1.83%percent1.831.83\%1.83 % approximately across three datasets on the validation and test sets, respectively, showcasing comparable unlearning generalizability and retention fidelity. We repeat the experiment 5 times using different seed values and report the standard deviation in Table 3. For the other types of unlearning, the standard deviation were found to be negligible and are therefore omitted.

Unlearning efficiency. On the baby dataset, MMRecUN takes 169.41169.41169.41169.41 seconds in contrast to 225.73225.73225.73225.73 seconds of Gold model. Similarly, on the clothing dataset, MMRecUN takes 968.96968.96968.96968.96 seconds in contrast to 1294.441294.441294.441294.44 seconds of Gold model. Thus, with MMRecUN, we experience up to 1.3×1.3\times1.3 × accelerated unlearning than retraining from scratch (Figure 2(b)). In other words, 25%percent2525\%25 % time is saved.

Tuning hyper-parameter α𝛼\mathbf{\alpha}italic_α. We evaluate the impact of α𝛼\alphaitalic_α on the balance between adaptation and reform in the unlearning process, experimenting with α𝛼\alphaitalic_α values from 0.0010.0010.0010.001 to 0.90.90.90.9 (Table 5). Lower α𝛼\alphaitalic_α values (0.10.10.10.1-0.20.20.20.2) effectively adapt to unlearning the forget set with minimal impact on retain set recall, and require fewer epochs for convergence, indicating an optimal balance. As α𝛼\alphaitalic_α increases (0.30.30.30.3-0.90.90.90.9), the model emphasizes more on the reform loss, needing more epochs to forget and adversely affecting retain set recall. Extremely low α𝛼\alphaitalic_α values (<0.01absent0.01<0.01< 0.01) hinder effective forgetting, also increasing epochs needed and negatively impacting retain set. The optimal α𝛼\alphaitalic_α depends on the specific task’s forgetting severity and time constraints: higher α𝛼\alphaitalic_α may ensure stronger forgetting with minor recall loss, while lower α𝛼\alphaitalic_α enables faster convergence. Some additional results are also presented in the Appendix A.

5 Conclusion

We introduce MMRecUN, a new framework for unlearning in MMRS. While previous methods are incompatible with the complex multi-modal data structures of MMRS, MMRecUN balances the removal of specified interactions with maintaining the recommendation model’s performance on retained interactions. Using a Reverse Bayesian Personalized Ranking (BPR) objective, MMRecUN attenuates the impact of interactions marked for forgetting while reinforcing the importance of retained interactions. Our experimental results validate the effectiveness of MMRecUN, demonstrating substantial improvements unlearning specificity, retention fidelity, generalizability and efficiency.

Appendix B Learning and Unlearning Workflows for Multi-modal Recommendation Systems

B.1 Training and Inference

In the traditional workflow, depicted in Fig. 1, the recommender model M⁢(⋅,φ)𝑀⋅𝜑M(\cdot,\varphi)italic_M ( ⋅ , italic_φ ) undergoes two key stages. During training, the model aims to encode collaborative signals inherent in the user-item interaction matrix 𝒴𝒴\mathcal{Y}caligraphic_Y, along with item-item semantic correlations, into embeddings EusubscriptE𝑢\textbf{E}_{u}E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_u end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for users and Ei,msubscriptE𝑖𝑚\textbf{E}_{i,m}E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i , italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for items in each modality m∈ℳ𝑚ℳm\in\mathcal{M}italic_m ∈ caligraphic_M.

To enhance the model’s ability to capture features across different modalities accurately, a behavior-aware fuser component is integrated. This component allows for flexible fusion weight allocation based on user modality preferences derived from behavior features. Additionally, a self-supervised auxiliary task is introduced to maximize the mutual information between behavior features and fused multi-modal features, promoting the exploration of behavior and multi-modal information. Refer to Mgcn paper [54] for details.

The optimization process involves minimizing the Bayesian Personalized Ranking (BPR) loss ℒBPRsubscriptℒBPR\mathcal{L}_{\text{BPR}}caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT BPR end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [36], augmented by auxiliary self-supervised tasks. This combined loss function, ℒℒ\mathcal{L}caligraphic_L, updates the model parameters φ𝜑\varphiitalic_φ, with hyper-parameters λCsubscript𝜆𝐶\lambda_{C}italic_λ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and λφsubscript𝜆𝜑\lambda_{\varphi}italic_λ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_φ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT controlling the impact of the contrastive auxiliary task and L2subscript𝐿2L_{2}italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT regularization, respectively.

These enhanced features are then utilized to compute the likelihood of interaction between a user u𝑢uitalic_u and an item i𝑖iitalic_i, represented by the inner product y^u,i=euT⁢eisubscript^𝑦𝑢𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑒𝑢𝑇subscript𝑒𝑖\hat{y}_{u,i}=e_{u}^{T}e_{i}over^ start_ARG italic_y end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_u , italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_u end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Finally, it recommends items to users based on these preference scores, prioritizing items with higher scores that have not been interacted with by the user.

B.2 Unlearning with Traditional Workflow: Retraining

To cater to demands for privacy, legal compliance, and evolving user preferences and content licensing grow, the recommender model M⁢(⋅,φ)𝑀⋅𝜑M(\cdot,\varphi)italic_M ( ⋅ , italic_φ ) has to adapt dynamically. Thus, either of the four unlearning requests can come up.

  1. 1.

    Single interaction removal (privacy needs): This request involves removing a single interaction between a user and an item from the model. It addresses privacy concerns by allowing users to delete specific interactions they no longer want associated with their profile. For example, if a user wants to remove a movie they watched from their viewing history for privacy reasons, the system would unlearn this interaction.

  2. 2.

    Multiple interaction removal (user preference adjustment, bias elimination): In this request, multiple interactions of the same user with different items or multiple interactions of the same item across many users are removed. It aims to adjust user preferences, eliminate bias, and mitigate shilling attacks [12] [39] by updating the model based on the removal of these interactions. Shilling attacks involve artificially inflating the ratings or interactions of certain items to manipulate recommendations, and this removal process helps counteract such malicious behavior.

  3. 3.

    Removal of all interactions of a user for account deletion (privacy laws): This request involves removing all interactions associated with a specific user from the model, effectively deleting their entire profile and history from the system to comply with privacy regulations.

  4. 4.

    Removal of all interactions related to an item (evolving license): In this request, all interactions related to a particular item are removed from the model. It addresses evolving content licensing agreements by adapting the model to the absence or unavailability of certain items. For instance, if a music label withdraws its catalog from the platform, the system would unlearn all interactions associated with songs from that label to comply with the licensing changes.

After receiving the requests, the recommendation system must execute two processes. The first process involves removing data from the database by nullifying interaction data in the interaction matrix, yu,i=0subscript𝑦𝑢𝑖0y_{u,i}=0italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_u , italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 0, ∀yu,i∈𝒴u+for-allsubscript𝑦𝑢𝑖superscriptsubscript𝒴𝑢\forall y_{u,i}\in\mathcal{Y}_{u}^{+}∀ italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_u , italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ caligraphic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_u end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. The second process requires retraining the recommendation model M⁢(⋅,φ)𝑀⋅𝜑M(\cdot,\varphi)italic_M ( ⋅ , italic_φ ) using the updated interaction matrix 𝒴𝒴\mathcal{Y}caligraphic_Y, following the training process specified by Eq. 12.

B.3 Proposed MMRecUN Workflow for Unlearning

As discussed in Section G, retraining the recommendation model from scratch poses computational inefficiencies due to the large volume of interactions and the size of the model itself. This challenge is further exacerbated when multiple unlearning requests occur sequentially over time. Hence, we advocate for unlearning the initially trained model M⁢(⋅,φ)𝑀⋅𝜑M(\cdot,\varphi)italic_M ( ⋅ , italic_φ ) using MMRecUN.

Appendix C Bayesian Interpretation of MMRecUN

We present the theoretical interpretation of the objective in equation 5 through the Bayesian theorem. Appendix D Time Complexity

The time complexity of unlearning LightGCN with BPR loss can be analyzed based on the dominant operations performed during each training iteration. Here’s a breakdown:

  1. 1.

    Forward Pass: LightGCN utilizes message passing to propagate information between connected nodes in the graph. This involves operations like matrix multiplication between the embedding matrices and the adjacency matrix. Complexity: 𝒪⁢(d⋅|ℰ|⋅dm)𝒪⋅𝑑ℰsubscript𝑑𝑚\mathcal{O}(d\cdot|\mathcal{E}|\cdot d_{m})caligraphic_O ( italic_d ⋅ | caligraphic_E | ⋅ italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) for each modality. Since there can be multiple modalities, this is summed over all modalities ℳℳ\mathcal{M}caligraphic_M.

  2. 2.

    Auxiliary Contrastive Loss Calculation: The complexity of the auxiliary contrastive loss calculation depends on the following operations. Refer to Mgcn paper [54] for details.

    1. (a)

      Calculation of Modality Preferences (Pmsubscript𝑃𝑚P_{m}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT): This step involves a matrix multiplication operation followed by applying a sigmoid non-linearity. Both have a complexity: 𝒪⁢(d×d)𝒪𝑑𝑑\mathcal{O}(d\times d)caligraphic_O ( italic_d × italic_d ).

    2. (b)

      Calculation of Modality-shared Features (Essubscript𝐸𝑠E_{s}italic_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT): This step includes attention mechanisms to calculate attention weights (αmsubscript𝛼𝑚\alpha_{m}italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT) for each modality’s features and then obtaining the modality-shared features by aggregating the weighted sum of modality features. Both have a complexity: 𝒪⁢(d×|ℳ|)𝒪𝑑ℳ\mathcal{O}(d\times|\mathcal{M}|)caligraphic_O ( italic_d × | caligraphic_M | ).

    3. (c)

      Calculation of Modality-specific Features (E~msubscript~𝐸𝑚\tilde{E}_{m}over~ start_ARG italic_E end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT): This step involves subtracting the modality-shared features from the original modality features. Complexity: 𝒪⁢(d)𝒪𝑑\mathcal{O}(d)caligraphic_O ( italic_d ).

    4. (d)

      Adaptive Fusion of Modality-specific and Modality-shared Features (Emulsubscript𝐸mulE_{\text{mul}}italic_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT mul end_POSTSUBSCRIPT): This step includes element-wise multiplication (⊙direct-product\odot⊙) and addition operations, both of which have a complexity: 𝒪⁢(d)𝒪𝑑\mathcal{O}(d)caligraphic_O ( italic_d ).

    5. (e)

      Self-supervised Auxiliary Task Loss (ℒCsubscriptℒ𝐶\mathcal{L}_{C}caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT): The complexity of this loss function depends on the number of users (|𝒰|𝒰|\mathcal{U}|| caligraphic_U |) and items (|ℐ|ℐ|\mathcal{I}|| caligraphic_I |) and is typically dominated by the number of interactions in the dataset.

    Summing up the complexities of these steps, we get the total time complexity for the auxiliary contrastive loss calculation: 𝒪⁢(d×d+d×|ℳ|+d+d+|𝒰|+|ℐ|)𝒪𝑑𝑑𝑑ℳ𝑑𝑑𝒰ℐ\mathcal{O}(d\times d+d\times|\mathcal{M}|+d+d+|\mathcal{U}|+|\mathcal{I}|)caligraphic_O ( italic_d × italic_d + italic_d × | caligraphic_M | + italic_d + italic_d + | caligraphic_U | + | caligraphic_I | ).   3. 3.

    BPR Loss Calculation: This step involves comparing the predicted preference scores for user-item pairs and their corresponding negative samples.

    Complexity: 𝒪⁢(|𝒰|⋅|ℐ|⋅K)𝒪⋅𝒰ℐ𝐾\mathcal{O}(|\mathcal{U}|\cdot|\mathcal{I}|\cdot K)caligraphic_O ( | caligraphic_U | ⋅ | caligraphic_I | ⋅ italic_K ), where |𝒰|𝒰|\mathcal{U}|| caligraphic_U | is the number of users, |ℐ|ℐ|\mathcal{I}|| caligraphic_I | is the number of items, and K𝐾Kitalic_K is the number of negative samples used per user-item pair.

  4. 4.

    Back-propagation: Back-propagation calculates gradients for all the parameters involved in the forward pass. This involves similar operations as the forward pass but with additional computations for gradients. The next step of parameter updates involves updating the model parameters based on the calculated gradients using an optimizer like SGD or Adam. Complexity is similar to the forward pass.

Summing the complexities of each step, we get the total time complexity for unlearning LightGCN with BPR loss and auxiliary contrastive loss in MMRecUN:

Appendix E Datasets and samples

In accordance with references [45] [57] [64], our research involves experimentation on three distinct categories within the popular Amazon dataset [20]: (a) Baby, (b) Sports and Outdoors, and (c) Clothing, Shoes, and Jewelry, abbreviated as Baby, Sports, and Clothing respectively. The details of these datasets are outlined in Table 9. As per the methodology described in  [64], we utilize pre-extracted visual features consisting of 4096409640964096 dimensions and textual features comprising 384384384384 dimensions, as previously documented in  [63].

The datasets from Amazon reviews contains various samples of user interactions with different products. It includes both implicit interactions, such as purchases, and explicit interactions, such as ratings. Additionally, the dataset comprises textual reviews, images of products, and detailed descriptions of the items.

Appendix F Discussion

Limitations: First, the method primarily focuses on user-item interactions without explicitly considering the temporal dynamics of interactions, which may be important in certain applications. Second, our approach assumes that the data to be forgotten is clearly identifiable, which might not always be the case in zero-shot unlearning scenarios.

Impact: MMRecUN offers significant positive societal impacts, such as enhanced privacy, increased user trust, ethical data handling, and improved recommendation quality by enabling users to control their data and align with privacy regulations like GDPR. However, it also presents potential negative impacts, including the risk of misuse for manipulation, loss of valuable insights, increased computational costs, unintended consequences on model behavior. For example, malicious actors might repeatedly request the unlearning of certain interactions to bias the system in a way that benefits them.

Future research can extend MMRecUN to handle more complex types of multi-modal data . Another promising direction is to investigate automated methods for identifying data to be forgotten, improving the practicality and robustness of unlearning in MMRS.

Appendix G Challenges in Multi-modal Recommendation Unlearning

Previous methods cannot be directly applied to multi-modal GCN-based recommender systems due to the following challenges.

Divergence in Model Representations: Multi-modal GCN models, incorporate heterogeneous user-item image, text and behavior information into a unified graph, contrasting with the matrices, latent factors, feature representations, and temporal sequences used in traditional recommender systems like CF, MF, CBF, and SRS, respectively. Consequently, transferring unlearning mechanisms is not as straight-forward.

Incompatibility with Uni-modal Approaches: Uni-modal recommender systems, even those based on GCNs, fail to directly apply to multi-modal GCN-based systems due to the inherent complexities of integrating diverse modalities [7]. Both the graph structure and feature embeddings are tightly integrated, making it non-trivial to modify one component without affecting the other. Unlearning interactions in one modality may have cascading effects on the representations and relationships within the entire graph.

Expensive operations: The computational overhead associated with computing the Hessian matrix or adjusting the interaction matrix or computing the inverse of Hessian for influence function or Fisher Information Matrix may become prohibitive as the size of the dataset or the number of interactions increases, making some of the methods less practical for large-scale recommender systems.

Ill-effects of sharding: Partitioning data breaks the graph structure. Partitioning based on items restricts the system’s ability to recommend items across different partitions to users, and partitioning based on users leads to insufficient training data and poor data heterogeneity [22]. This causes a significant drop (∼30%similar-toabsentpercent30\sim 30\%∼ 30 %) in performance [53]. This adds unlearning overhead of extra computational cost and time at the time of training . When items that need to be forgotten come from multiple shards, the worst case efficiency falls to the level of retraining from scratch. The model’s initial setup, partitioned based on users during training, poses a challenge to implementing item-related data unlearning, as it cannot be readily reconfigured to partition data based on items. Item-related data unlearning concurrently with user-related data unlearning is not possible.

Burden of aggregation: Additional steps to aggregate performance across shards introduce significant overhead costs, with the burden increasing proportionally to the number of shards [35]. This adds unlearning overhead of extra computational cost and time at the time of inference. The partition-aggregation framework is prohibitive for the models which have already been trained.

These constraints underscore the need for tailored methodologies specifically designed for unlearning in multi-modal recommender systems.

Appendix H Related Work

Recommender Systems. Recommender systems can be categorized into various types based on their underlying techniques. These include collaborative filtering (CF), matrix factorization (MF), content-based filtering (CBF), sequential recommender systems (SRS), graph convolutional network-based (GCN) and hybrids of these systems. Recent advancements have seen a surge in research on multi-modal recommender systems  [51] [45] [46] [31], which leverage multiple modalities such as text, images, and videos to enhance recommendation accuracy and user satisfaction. The current state-of-the-art Mgcn [54], a GCN model, leverages multiple views to separate modality features and behavior features, enhancing feature discriminability, and considers the relative importance of different modalities for improved user preference modeling.

Machine Unlearning. In recent years, significant advancements have been made in the field of machine unlearning [2] [1] across various domains such as image classification [40] [9] [8], regression [41], federated learning [47], graph learning [6] [43], and more. Exact unlearning [1] aims to completely remove the influence of specific data points from the model through algorithmic-level retraining. The advantage is the model will behave as if the unlearned data had never been seen. While providing strong guarantees of removal, exact unlearning usually demands extensive computational resources and is primarily suitable for simpler models. Approximate unlearning focuses on efficiently minimizing the influence of target data points through limited parameter-level updates to the model. While not removing influence entirely, approximate unlearning significantly reduces computational and time costs. It enables practical unlearning applications even for large-scale and complex machine learning models, where exact retraining is infeasible.

Multi-modal Machine Unlearning. In Mmul [7], unlearning is accomplished by minimizing the dissimilarity between the multi-modal representations of deleted pairs and randomly drawn unassociated pairs. At the same time, uni-modal and multi-modal knowledge is preserved by minimizing the difference between the uni-modal and multi-modal representations produced by the unlearned model and the original model.

Recommendation Unlearning. Various methods for unlearning have been explored in different types of recommender systems as summarized in Table 10. For collaborative filtering, Caboose [37] incrementally adjusts the user-item matrices and re-calculates similarities only for affected entries to reflect the removal of a specific interaction. This approach avoids complete re-computation, effectively conserving computational resources. Laser [28] partitions users according to collaborative embedding and trains them sequentially with curriculum learning.

For matrix factorization, IMCorrect [30] adjusts the interaction matrix by weakening item pairs’ similarity if they had high similarity due to similar interaction patterns in the removed interactions, reflecting the unlearned recommendations. In another workCmumf [60], performs a closed-form unlearning update based on the total Hessian-based Newton step, allowing for the efficient removal of the influence of specific rows or columns from the trained MF factors. ALS [50] modifies the intermediate confidence matrix used in Alternating Least Squares to achieve fast forgetting. AltEraser [33] unlearns via alternating optimization in Alternating Least squares.

For sequential recommender systems, DyRand [52] leverages label noise injection to make random predictions for sequences to be unlearned. Among uni-modal GCN-based systems, exact unlearning has been investigated by RecEraser [4]. It partitions training set into shards, train sub-models and employs attention-based adaptive aggregation strategies to combine performance of shards. For unlearning, one of the sub-models whose shard contains the interaction to be unlearned and the aggregation part needs to be retrained. UltraRE [25] improves partitioning by optimal balanced clustering and aggregation by logistic regression.

Among uni-modal GCN-based systems, approximate unlearning has been explored by Ifru [61] which updates the model based on influence of data to be unlearned. Scif [26] improves by selectively updating user embeddings based on their collaborative influence. Rrl [53] uses reverse BPR loss to unlearn and Fisher Information Matrix to preserve remaining user-item interactions. Though, computing the inverse of Hessian for influence function and Fisher Information Matrix are computationally expensive operations. Other related work includes federated unlearning for on-device recommendation [56], attribute unlearning [27] [3], [13], unlearning session-based recommendations [49], and unlearning LLMs fine-tuned for recommendation [44].
